images.caption: Figure 1:Overall performance across five competition-level benchmarks (MATH-500, AIME 2024, AMC, OlmpiadBench, and Minerva Math). TAPO significantly outperforms existing RL methods, especially on the challenging AIME and AMC benchmark (↑↑\uparrow↑99%percent\%%and↑↑\uparrow↑41%percent\%%over GRPO).

Figure 2:Flowchart of TAPO: Enhancing policy model capabilities through integration of external guidance (high-level thought patterns). This thought augmentation establishes an optimal balance between model internal exploration and external strategy exploitation.
Figure 3:Schematic diagram of action-chain-structured solution trajectory.
Figure 4:Results on three out-of-distribution benchmark datasets (Qwen2.5-Math-7B-Base).
Figure 7:Comparison of GRPO and TAPO for a simple geometry problem from the MATH dataset.
Figure 8:An illustration of four phases in an iteration of MCTS for complex reasoning tasks.
Figure 9:The system prompt used for all experiments.
Figure 10:Comparison of GRPO and TAPO for a simple algorithm problem from the MATH dataset.
Figure 11:Comparison of GRPO and TAPO for a difficult algorithm problem from the MATH dataset.
